turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I was surprised to get your note. My daughter hadn't told me anything about you. About your helping her.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's typical of your daughter. Takes those things for granted.  Why does she think I lugged her all the way from Miami  for the love of it?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Please understand me. When I say she didn't tell me anything about it, I mean not until a little while ago. She thinks you're entitled to anything you can get.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, she does, huh? Isn't that sweet of her! You don't , I suppose.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: don't know. I'd have to see on what you base your claim. I presume you feel you're justified in

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If I didn't I wouldn't be here!  I've got it all itemized.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I sold some drawers and socks, too; I'm throwing those in.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: And this is what you wantthirty- nine dollars and sixty cents?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why not? I'm not charging you for the time I wasted.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Yes, I knowbut

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's the matter? Isn't it cheap enough? A trip like that would cost you a thousand dollars!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Let me get this straight. You want this thirty-nine sixty in addition to the ten thousand dollars?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What ten thousand?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: The reward.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Who said anything about a reward!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I'm afraid I'm a little confused. You see, I assumed you were coming here for

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: All I want is thirty-nine sixty. If you'll give me a check I'll get out of this place. It gives me the jitters.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: You're a peculiar chap.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We'll go into that some other time.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: The average man would go after the reward. All you seem to

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Listen, did anybody ever make a sucker out of you? This is a matter of principle. Something you probably wouldn't understand.  When somebody takes me for a buggy ride I don't like the idea of having to pay for the privilege.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: You were taken for a buggy ride?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeahwith all the trimmings. Now, how about the check. Do I get it?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Here you are.  Do you mind if I ask you something frankly?  Do you love my daughter?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: A guy that'd fall in love with your daughter should have his head examined.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: That's an evasion.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: She grabbed herself a perfect running mate. King Westley! The pill of the century!  What she needs is a guy that'd take a sock at her every daywhether it's coming to her or not.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If you had half the brains you're supposed to have, you'd have done it yourselflong ago.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Do you love her?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: A normal human being couldn't live under the same roof with her, without going nuts.  She's my idea of nothing!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I asked you a question. Do you love her?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yes!  But don't hold that against me. I'm a little screwy myself.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: What's this about not eating?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't want to eat!  And there's one more thing I don't want! Definitely! That's to see you.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Know what my next move is? No more cigarettes.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why don't you put me in chains?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I might.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: All right! Put me in chains! Do anything you want!  But I'm not going to eat a thing until you let me off this boat!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Come on, Ellie. Stop being silly. You know I'm going to have my way.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I won't stand for it! I won't stand for your running my life! Why do you insist on it!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: You ought to know why. Because

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes. I know.  Because I'm your daughter and you love me. Because you don't want me to make any mistakes. Because

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Because marrying that fool King Westley is

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're wasting your time. I'm already married to him.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Not so far as I'm concerned, you're not.  Yes?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Smart, aren't you! So subtle.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: If Gandhi had a chef like Paul, it would change the whole political situation in India.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You can't tempt me.  Do you hear? I won't eat!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Please. I can't fight on an empty stomach. Remember what Napoleon said.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I hope you're not comparing yourself to Napoleon. He was a strategist. Your idea of strategy is to use a lead pipe.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Where are you taking me?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: South America.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: South America!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: We leave Miami in an hour. Soon's we get some supplies aboard.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You'll have a corpse on your hands! That what You'll have. I won't eat a thing while I'm on this boat.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: In that event, we won't need so many supplies.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What do you expect to accomplish by all this? I'm already married!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I'll get it annulled.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You'll never do it! You can't do it!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I'll do it if it takes every penny I've got. I'll do it if I have to bribe that musical comedy Justice of the Peace! I'll do itif I have to prove that you were dragged in, staggering drunk. You probably were.  Mmmmmm. This filet mignon is divine!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What've you got against King Westley?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Nothing much. I just think he's a fake, that's all.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You only met him once .

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: That was enough. Do you mind handing me the ketchup?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You talk as if he were a gigoloor something.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Never mindI'll get it myself.  Gigolo? Why, you took the word right out of my mouth. Thanks.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: He's one of the best fliers in the country. Right now he's planning a trip to Japan.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: You're going to finance him, I suppose.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why not?  Look what he's doing for aviation. It takes courage to do what he does. And character! At least he's accomplished something worthwhile. I suppose you'd like to have me marry a business man. Well, I hate business menparticularly if you're a shining example.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Your whole life is devoted to just one thing. To accumulate more money. At least there's romance in what he's doing.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: He's no good, Ellie, and you know it. You married him only because I told you not to.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You've been telling me what not to do since I was old enough to remember.  I'm sick of it!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: A time will come when you'll thank me for this.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I won't thank you! I'll never thank you!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Please don't shout.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'll shout to my heart's content! I'll scream if I want to.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Ah! Coconut layer cake. Nice and gooey, too. Just the way I like it.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Ellie

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, hello, Dad.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I knocked several times.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Sorry. Must have been day-dreaming.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Well, everything's set. Creating quite a furor, too. Great stunt King's going to pull.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Stunt?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Landing on the lawn in an autogyro.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, yes. I heard.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Yes. Personally, I think it's silly, too.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: What's the matter, Ellie? What's wrong?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: You've been acting so strangely since you returned. I'mI'm worried. I haven't bothered to ask you any questionsI  Isn't all this what you wanted?  You haven't changed your mind about King, have you?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, no.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: If you have, it isn't too late. You know how I feel about him. But I want to make you happy. You gave me such a scareIwhen I couldn't find you.  You know, the old pump isn't what it used to be.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Sorry, Dad. I wouldn't hurt you for the world. You know that.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I haven't seen you cry since you were a baby. This must be serious.  Where'd you meet him?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: On the road.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Now, don't tell me you fell in love with a bus driver!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Who is he?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't know very much about him.  Except that I love him.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Well, if it's as serious as all thatwe'll move heaven and earth to

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It'll do no good.  He despises me.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Oh, come now

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: He despises everything I stand for. He thinks I'm spoiled and pampered, and selfish, and thoroughly insincere.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Ridiculous!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: He doesn't think so much of you either.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Well!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: He blames you for everything that's wrong about me. Thinks you raised me stupidly.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Fine man to fall in love with.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: He's marvelous!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Well, what are we going to do about it? Where is he?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I'd like to have a talk with him.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's no use, Dad. I practically threw myself at him.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Well, under the circumstances, don't you think we ought to call this thing off?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No, I'll go through with it.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: But that's silly, child. Seeing how you feel, why

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It doesn't matter.  I don't want to stir up any more trouble. I've been doing it all my life. I've been such a burden to youmade your life so miserableand mine, too. I'm tired, Dad. Tired of running around in circles. He's right, that's what I've been doing ever since I can remember.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes, I guess I have.  I don't want to hurt anybody any more. I want to get away from all this front page publicity. It suddenly strikes me as being cheap and loathsome. I can't walk out on King now. It'll make us all look so ridiculous.  Besides, what difference does it make?  I'll never see Peter again.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Is that his name?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes. Peter Warne.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Peter Warne!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why? Do you know him?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Oh, nono.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You haven't heard from him, have you, Dad?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Why, no . . . Don't be silly.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, please, Dad

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Looks like that was his only interest in me. The reward.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I'm sorry you read it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Are you going to see him?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I suppose so.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Certainly!  Pay him off. He's entitled to it. He did an excellent job. Kept me thoroughly entertained. It's worth every penny he gets.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I'll be going.  Ellie swallows her drink and starts pouring herself another, as King enters.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well, if it isn't the groom himself! You're just in time, King.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: might have been able to help if it weren't for you. I've been watched so closely, I

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Yes. I know. Well, you can help now. I issued a statement yesterday that I've withdrawn my objections. Begging her to come home. I haven't heard from her. Apparently she doesn't trust me.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: Why should she? After all

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: All right. That's why I sent for you.  There's a room full of reporters out there. I want you to make a statementthat you've had a talk with methat we've reached an understandingthat if Ellen comes home, I won't interfere with your marriage. Will you do that?

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: If you really mean it, I will.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Of course I mean it! I don't care whom she's married to  as long as I can get her back.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: On a hunger strike, huh?  When'd she eat last?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: She hasn't had a thing yesterdayor today.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Been sending her meals in regularly?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Yessir. She refuses them all.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Why didn't you jam it down her throat?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: It's not quite that simple.  I've dealt with prisoners in my time, but this one

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Absurd!  All this fuss over a snip of a girl.  I'm going down to see her myself.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: It's my daughter! Go after her.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Lower the boats!

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: What a hell cat. No controlling these modern girls.  They're terrible!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Terrible! Nothing terrible about her. She's great! Marvelous youngster! Got a mind of her own. Knows just what she wants.  She's not going to get it though. She won't get very far. Has no money.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: What about that diamond wrist watch she had onshe can raise some money on that?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Holy Smoke! I forgot all about that.  Send a wireless at once, "Lovington Detective Agency. Daughter escaped again. Watch all roadsall transports and railroad stations in Miami. Have your New York office keep tabs on King Westley. Intercept all messages. Want her back at all costs!"

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I haven't changed my mind, Westley, I want you to understand that! I don't like you! I never have!  I never will! That's clear enough, isn't it?

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: You've made that quite evidentwith all your threats of annulment.  Well, it hasn't bothered me for a minute. Ellie and I got married because we love each other. And she's proving it; as far as I'm concerned there's going to be no annulment.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: You've got a good thing and you're hanging on to it, huh?  All right, You win. I'll just have to get used to you. I admit I'm licked. But only because I'm worried. I've had detectives all over the country searching for her. I've seen thousands of photographs. Fortune tellers, nuts, every crank in the country has written me.  Haven't slept one night this week. If I don't find her, I'll go crazy.

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: Why; naturally, I

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Naturally.  You're going to become a partner in a big institution. It's one of the largest in the world.

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: You talk as if

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Someday perhaps, you might even take charge.

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: Ellie? Oh, she's no responsibility.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: No?  Say, listenI've devoted a whole lifetime trying to tame that wildcat. Toughest job I ever tackled. Ever hear of J.P. Clarkson? Biggest man in the country, isn't he? Well, I tamed him . Got him eating out of the palm of my hand. I've browbeaten financiers, statesmen, foreign ministerssome of the most powerful people in the worldbut I've never been able to do a thing with her. She's been too much for me. I'm glad you think it's easy.  Now listenif you'll do what I tell you, perhaps I might develop a little respect for you. You never can tell.

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: What would you like to have me do?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Sock her!

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Try. Do me a favor. Try. It's your only chance. And hers, too. Do that for meand maybe we'll be friends  Maybe.  Do we understand each other?

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Fine. I'll see you at the reception.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: You thought that up all by yourself, huh?

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: Why, it'll make all the front pages. A spectacular thing like that

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Personally, I think it's stupid!  But go ahead. Have a good time. As long as Ellie doesn't object.

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: Oh, no. She'll be crazy about it. Well, see you later. I'm going out on the lawn and arrange for landing space.  Goodbye.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: We've done that already.

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: Yes, of course.

turns.speaker: KING
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I haven't the slightest idea.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Here's another wire, sir. This one's from Charleston.  "Checking every northbound train. Also assigned twenty operatives to watch main highways. No success yet. Will continue to do everything possible." Signed: Lovington Detective Agency, Charleston.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Any others?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Yessir.  There's a report here from every State along the East coast. Want to hear them?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: What do they say?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: They're practically all the same, sir.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Amateurs!

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: They're the finest detective agency in the country, sir.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Don't want to talk todon't want to talk to anybody. Don't want to see anybody.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: But it's King Westley on the phone.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Ooooooh.  Hello my would-be ex-son-in-law. I've sent you a check for a hundred thousand. Yes. That's the smartest thing you ever did, Westley, not to contest that annulment. That's satisfactory, isn't it? Yeah. Well, it ought to be. Oh I'm not complaining. It was dirt cheap.  Don't fall out of any windows.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: There's another wire from Peter, sir. They're in Glen Falls, Michigan.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: "What's holding up the annulment, you slow poke? The Walls of Jericho are toppling."  Send him a telegram right away. Just say: "Let 'em topple."

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Never mind, son. She doesn't want it.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: But the lady says

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: We ain't ate nothin' since yestidday.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What happened to your money?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Ma spent it all for the tickets. She didn't know it was gonna be so much.  We shouldn'a come, I guess, but Ma said there's a job waitin' for her in New Yorkand if we didn't go, she might lose it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Going without food is bad business, son. Why didn't you ask somebody?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: I was gonna do it, but Ma wouldn't let me. She was ashamed, I guess.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Me? Forget it, son.  I got millions.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hey, hey, aren't you afraid you'll burn out a tonsil?

turns.speaker: DANKER
turns.text: Tonsil? Me? No! Me burn a tonsil?  "My tonsils won't burn As life's corners I . . .

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: All right, let it go.

turns.speaker: DANKER
turns.text: . . . turn."

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No, thanks. We're not hungry.

turns.speaker: DANKER
turns.text: Oh, I see, young people in love are never hungry.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DANKER
turns.text: "Young people in love Are very seldom hungry. People in love Are very seldom hungry . . ."

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Whadda you want!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If you'll be good enough to remove those newspapers I'll have a seat.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Okay! Okay! Keep your shirt on, young feller.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Just between you and me, I never intended taking it off.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: What do you think you're doing!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: The papers! The papers! Whadda you mean throwin' 'em out!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Ohthe papers

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's a long story, my friend. You see, I don't like sitting on newspapers. I did once and all the headlines came off on my white pants.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Hey, whadda you tryin' to dokid me?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, I wouldn't kid you . On the level, it actually happened. Nobody bought a paper that day. They followed me all over town and read the news from the seat of my pants.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: What're you gonna do about the papers? Somebody's gotta pick 'em up.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's okay with me. I'm not arguing.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Fresh guy, huh! What you need is a good sock on the nose.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Look here, partner. You may not like my nose. But I do. It's a good nose. The only one I've got. I always keep it out in the open where anybody can take a sock at it. If you decide to do it, make sure you don't miss.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Oh, yeah?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Now, that's a brilliant answer. Why didn't I think of it? Our conversation could have been over long ago.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Oh, yeah?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You win!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Driver!

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: These seats accommodate two passengers, don't they?

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Maybe they doand maybe they don't.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: That storm sure made a mess outa these roads.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Holy Smokes! You'll never get out yourself! Better phone for some help.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Phone for help?  We're right in the middle of nowhere. There isn't a town within ten miles of here.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I beg your pardon!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Now, listen. I'm in a very ugly mood. I put up a stiff battle for that seat. So if it's just the same to you  scram.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Driver!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Tell that man not to drive so fast.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Are you talking to me?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes. Tell that man to drive slowly.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't know what you're raving about, young man. And, furthermore, I'm not interested.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Wellof all thewell  Maybe you'll be interested to know your bag's gone.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, my heavens! It's gone!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah. I knew you'd catch on eventually.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That cadaverous-looking yegg who sat in front of us, just up and took it. Boy, how that baby can run!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What am I going to do now?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Don't tell me your ticket was in it?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No, I've got that, all right. But my money. All I have here is four dollars. I've got to get to New York with it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You can wire home for some money when we get to Jacksonville.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why, noI  Yes . . . I guess I will.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'll report it to the driver. About your bag, I mean.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No. I'd rather you didn't.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Don't be a fool. You lost your bag. The company'll make good. What's your name?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't want it reported!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why, that's ridiculous! They're responsible for everything that

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: See here, can you understand English! I don't want it reported!  Please stay out of my affairs!  I want to be left alone.  A CLOSE-UP of PETER shows him glaring after her.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why, you ungrateful brat!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, thank you.  We're in Jacksonville, aren't we?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That was foolish of me. Why didn't you shove me away?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I hated to wake you up.  How about some breakfast?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No, thank you.  Thank you so much.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Remember me? I'm the fellow you slept on last night.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Seems to me I've already thanked you for that.  What time is the next bus to New York?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's the matter? Wouldn't the old meanies wait for you?  Say, how old are you anyway? Don't you know these busses work on a schedule? You need a guardian.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What are you excited about? You missed the bus, too.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Don't tell me you did it on my account!  hope you're not getting any idea that what happened last night is  You needn't concern yourself about me, young man. I can take care of myself.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're doing a pretty sloppy job of it.  Here's your ticket.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: My ticket?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I found it on the seat.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, thank you. Must have fallen out of my pocket.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You'll never get away with it, Miss Andrews.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Just a spoiled brat of a rich man. You and Westley'll make an ideal team.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Will you please tell me what you're raving about!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You'll never get away with it, Miss Andrews. Your father'll stop you before you get half way to New York.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You must have me confused with

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Quit kidding!  It's all over the front pages, You know, I've always been curious about the kind of a girl that would marry King Westley.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Take my advicegrab the first bus back to Miami. That guy's a phony.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I didn't ask for your advice.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's right. You didn't.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're not going to notify my father, are you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: If you play your cards right, you might get some money out of it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I never thought of that.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Listen, if you'll promise not to do it, I'll pay you. I'll pay you as much as he will. You won't gain anything by giving me away as long as I'm willing to make it worth your while. I've got to get to New York without being stopped. It's terribly important to me. I'd pay now, only the only thing I had when I jumped off the yacht was my wrist watch and I had to pawn that to get these clothes. I'll give you my address and you can get in touch with me the minute you get to New York.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Never mind. You know I had you pegged right from the start, you're the spoiled brat of a rich father. The only way you can get anything is to buy it. Now you're in a jam and all you can think of is your money. It never fails, does it? Ever hear of the word "Humility"? No, you wouldn't. I guess it never occurred to you to just say, "Please mister, I'm in trouble. Will you help me?" No; that'd bring you down off your high horse for a minute. Let me tell you something; maybe it'd take a load off your mind. You don't have to worry about me. I'm not interested in your money or your problems. You, King Westley, your father, you're all a lot of hooey to me.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: If you promise not to snap my head off, I'd like to thank you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Forget it. I didn't do it for you. His voice got on my nerves.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Here, boy!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What'd you do? Wire one of your friends for money?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No. It'd be useless. Father'd get the wire before they would.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Of course I do. What do you mean

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Beat it!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You have your nerve!  Here, boy!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: A dollar sixty! . . . You had four dollars last night! How do you expect to get to New York at the rate you're going?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That's none of your business.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're on a budget from now on.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Now, just a minuteyou can't

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hey, Brat!  The VIEW moves to the rear door of the bus. Ellie stands on the bottom step.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Are you talking to me!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah. Come onwe're stopping here for the night.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Darn clever, these Armenians.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah. Yeah, it's a gift.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I just had the unpleasant sensation of hearing you referred to as my husband.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, I forgot to tell you. I registered as Mr. and Mrs.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, you did? What am I expected to doleap for joy?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I kind of half expected you to thank me.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Your ego is colossal.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah. Yeah, not bad. How's your's?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Chalk up one for your side. Now listen, you want to get to King Westley, don't you?  All right, I'm here to help you. What I want is your story, exclusive. A day-to- day account. All about your mad flight to happiness. I need that story. Just between you and me I've got to have it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Now isn't that just too cute? There's a brain behind that face of yours, isn't there? You've got everything nicely figured out, for yourself, including this.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: This?  Oh, that's a matter of simple mathematics. These cabins cost two bucks a night and I'm very sorry to inform you, wifey dear, but the family purse won't stand for our having separate establishments.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well, thank you. Thank you very much, but you've been very kind.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, yeah? It's all right with me. Go on out in the storm, but I'm going to follow you, see?  Yeah. And if you get tough I'll just have to turn you over to your old man right now. Savvy?  Now that's my whole plot in a nutshell. A simple story for simple people. Now if you behave yourself, I'll see that you get to King Westley; if not, I'll just have to spill the beans to papa. Now which of these beds do you prefer? This one? All right.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That, I suppose, makes everythinguhquite all right.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, this?I like privacy when I retire. I'm very delicate in that respect. Prying eyes annoy me.  Behold the walls of Jericho![4] Maybe not as thick as the ones that Joshua blew down with his trumpet, but a lot safer. You see, I have no trumpet.  Now just to show you my heart's in the right place, I'll give you my best pair of pajamas.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Do you mind joining the Israelites?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're not really serious about this, are you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: All right, don't join the Israelites. Perhaps you're interested in how a man undresses.  Funny thing about that. Quite a study in psychology. No two men do it alike.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I have an idiosyncrasy all my own. You'll notice my coat came firstthen the tiethen the shirtnow, according to Hoyle,[5] the pants should come next. But that's where I'm different.  go for the shoes first. After that I

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Smart aleck!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Do you mind putting out the light?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Who, me?  Why, I'm the whippoorwill that cries in the night. I'm the soft morning breeze that caresses your lovely face.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You've got a name, haven't you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah. I got a name. Peter Warne.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Peter Warne? I don't like it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Don't let it bother you. You're giving it back to me in the morning.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Pleased to meet you, Mr. Warne ...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: The pleasure is all mine.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Here

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What is it?  Why, it's a toothbrush! Thanks.  Youyou had it pressed.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Come on! Hurry up! Breakfast'll be ready in no time.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why, you sweet thing, you. Where'd you get it pressed?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Listen, BratI'm going to count to ten. If you're not out of bed by then I'm going to yank you out myself.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You'll find the showersand thingsright back of the second cottage.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Outside!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Certainly, outside. All the best homes have 'em outside.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I can't go out like this.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Like this. I have no robe.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Heretake mine.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Where'd you say the showersand thingswere?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Heyyou're little, aren't you?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Where is the shower?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Your hair's cute like that. You should never comb it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'll find it myself.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: High time you got back.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I met some very interesting women at the showers. We got to chatting about this and that. You know how time files.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Very outspoken, too. Said I looked funny. Wasn't that cute?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hurry up and get dressed.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why, Peter! Don't you want to hear about our lovely friends?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If you didn't waste so much time on that wise-cracking drummerwe'd have been through with breakfast by this time.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well, I hope you're not going to dictate whom I can talk to.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I know a couple of truck drivers I'd like to have you meet sometime.  Come on, sit down.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Thank you.  My, my! Scrambled eggs.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Egg. One eggdoughnutsblack coffee. That's your ration till lunch. Any complaints?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Nope. No complaints.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'd have gotten you some cream but it meant buying a whole pint.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why, you don't have to apologize, Mr. Warne. You'll never know how much I appreciate all this.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What makes you so disgustingly cheerful this morning?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Must be the Spring.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I thought maybeuh"believe you me" told you a couple of snappy stories.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: He apologized for last night.  Said he didn't know we were married.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Just shows you how wrong a guy can be. Doughnut?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Thanks.  You think this whole business is silly, don't you? I mean running away and everything.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No. No. It's too good a story.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes, you do. You think I'm a fool and a spoiled brat. Perhaps I am, although I don't see how I can be. People who are spoiled are accustomed to having their own way. I never have. On the contrary, I've always been told what to do and how to do it and where and with whom. Would you believe it? This is the first time I've ever been alone with a man!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's a wonder I'm not panic stricken.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Um. You're doing all right.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Thanks. Nurses, governesses, chaperones, even body-guards. Oh, it's been a lot of fun.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: One consolation; you can never be lonesome.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It has its moments. It got to be a sort of game to try to outwit father's detectives. II did it once; actually went shopping without a body-guard. It was swell. I felt absolutely immoral. But it didn't last long. They caught up with me in a department store. I was so mad I ran out the back way and jumped into the first car I saw. Guess who was in it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Santa Claus?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: KingKing Westley was in it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh. Is that how you met him?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Um-hm. We rode around all afternoon. Father was frantic. By 6 o'clock he was having all the rivers dragged.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Say, where did you learn to dunk, in finishing school?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Aw, now, don't you start telling me I shouldn't dunk.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Of course you shouldn't. You don't know how to do it. Dunking's an art. Don't let it soak so long. A dip and plop, into your mouth. If you let it soak so long, it'll get soft and fall off. It's all a matter of timing. I ought to write a book about it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Thanks, professor.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Just goes to show you. Twenty millions and you don't know how to dunk.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'd change places with a plumber's daughter any day.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Detectives!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That's Father at work, What'll I do?  Peter, what'll I do?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Don't look at me. I didn't marry King Westley.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah. I got a letter from Aunt Betty. She says if we don't stop over at Wilkes-Barre she'll never forgive us.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Don't get excited, Peter. They just asked a civil question.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: There you go again! How many times did I tell you to stop butting in when I have an argument?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well, you don't have to lose your temper!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You don't have to lose your temper!  That's what you told me the last time too. Every time I step in to protect you. At the Elk's dance[7] when that big Swede made a pass at you

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: He didn't make a pass at me! I told you a million times!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, so now I was drunk!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well, you were!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm sorry I didn't take another sock at him.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yeah, and gotten yourself arrested!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Aw, nuts! You're just like your old man!  Once a plumber always a plumber! There isn't an ounce of brains in your whole family!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Peter Warne, you've gone far enough. I won't stand being insulted like this another minute.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Say, you were pretty good. Jumping in like that. Got a brain, haven't you?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You weren't so bad yourself.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We could start a two-person stock company. If things get toughwe can play some small town auditoriums. We'll call this one "The Great Deception."[8]

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Next week "East Lynne."

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: After that "The Three Musketeers."  I'd make a great D'Artagnan.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: How about Cinderellaor a real hot love story?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No mushy stuff. I'm running this troupe.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, you are! Who made you the manager?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I did! It was my idea, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You always want to run everything.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If you don't like it, you can resign from the company.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I refuse to resign!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Then I'll fire you. I'll do all the parts myself.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I better go over and see her.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Don't be silly. Nothing you can do. Must be tough on an old womana trip like this.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Poor old Shapeley. You shouldn't have frightened him like that.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: At the rate he started, he's probably passed two state lines by this time. The exercise is good for him.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes, I noticed he was getting a little fat lately.  Ouch!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I was never built for these moonlight strolls.  Why did we have to leave the bus?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I don't trust that chatterbox.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: First town we hit in the morning, you better wire your father.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Not as long as I'm alive.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Okay with me, if you can stand the starvation diet.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What do you meanstarvation?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It takes money to buy food.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why, haven't you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Not a sou. I had some before the fainting scene.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You didn't give that boy all your money?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I didn't give him anything . You were the big-hearted gal. How about wiring your father now?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Never! I'll get to New York if I have to starve all the way.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Must be some strange power Westley has over you women.  How do you expect to get there?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: To New York?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm following you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Aren't you afraid of me?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Okay. Hang on to these.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I wish you'd stop being playful.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Sorry.  It's the first time I've ridden "piggy-back" in years.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: This isn't "piggy-back."

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Of course it is.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're crazy.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: remember distinctly Father taking me for a "piggy-back" ride

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And he carried you like this, I suppose.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Your father didn't know beans about "piggy-back" riding.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: My uncleMother's brotherhad four children . . . and I've seen them ride "piggy-back."

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I don't think there's a "piggy- back" rider in your whole family. I never knew a rich man yet who was a good "piggy-back" rider.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That's silly.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: To be a "piggy-backer" it takes complete relaxationa warm heartand a loving nature.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And rich people have none of those qualifications, I suppose.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Not a one.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're prejudiced.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Show me a good "piggy-back" rider and I'll show you somebody that's human. Take Abraham Lincoln, for instancea natural "piggy-backer."  Where do you get off with your stuffed-shirt family?  Why, your father knew so much about "piggy-back" riding that he

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: This looks like the best spot.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: We're not going to sleep out here, are we?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I don't know about you, but I'm going to give a fairly good imitation of it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Peter

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If you're scared it scares the hunger out of you.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Not if you're more hungry than scared.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: All right. You win. Let's forget it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I can't forget it. I'm still hungry.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Holy Smokes! Why did I ever get mixed up with you!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'll get my clothes all wrinkled.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well, take them off.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: All right! Don't take them off. Do whatever you please. But shut up about it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, Peter

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's got into you?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, Peter! I was so scared.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I wasn't gone more than a minute. Just went out to find you something to eat.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: knowbut

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Here. Eat your head off.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't want it now.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thought you were hungry!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: wasbut

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: But what!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: was so scaredthat it scared

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Holy Jumping Catfish! You can drive a guy crazy.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Nothing.  Nothing you'd give two cents for.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Try me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I am. I only work when I have to. Two years ago I got a notion and went to China. There was a war going on. Swell! After a while it got stale. I went down to Tahiti. Just lay on the beach for six months. What could be sweeter?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Doesn't sound very exciting.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What are you thinking about?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: By a strange coincidence, I was thinking of you.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah. I was just wondering what makes dames like you so dizzy.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What'd you say we're supposed to be doing?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hitch-hiking.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well, you've given me a very good example of the hiking

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: If it's just the same to you, we'll sit right here till they come.  Got a toothpick?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No. But I've got a penknife.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Hayin my teeth.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: There it is. Better swallow it. We're not going to have any breakfast.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Needn't rub it in.  What're you eating?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Carrots.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Raw?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Uh-huh. Want one?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No!!  It's a wonder you couldn't get me something I can eat.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You don't think I'm going around panhandling for you.  Best thing in the world for youcarrots. Had a tough time getting them. If that farmer ever caught megoodnight!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I hate the horrid stuff.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I wish you wouldn't talk too much. We let a car get away.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What if nobody stops for us?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, they'll stop, all right. It's a matter of knowing how to hail them.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're an expert, I suppose.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Expert! Going to write a book on it. Called the "Hitch-Hikers Hail."

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: There's no end to your accomplishments.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You think it's simple, huh?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, no!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well, it is simple. It's all in the thumb, see? A lot of people do it

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: But the thumb always works. Different ways to do it, though. Depends on how you feel. For instance, number one is a short, jerky movement  That shows independence. You don't care if they stop or not. 'Cause you got some money in your pocket, see?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Clever.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Number two is a wider movementa smile goes with that onelike this.  That means you got a couple of brand new stories about the farmer's daughter.[12]

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You figured that all out yourself, huh?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, that's nothing. Now take number three, for instance. That's a pip. It's the pathetic one. When you're brokeand hungryand everything looks black. It's a long movement like this  with a follow through.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Amazing.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hm? Yeah, but it's no good if you haven't got a long face with it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Here comes a car!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Now watch me. I'm going to use Number One. Keep your eye on that thumb, baby, and see what happens.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Something must have gone wrong. I guess I'll try number two.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: When you get up to a hundred, wake me up.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I guess maybe I won't write that book after all.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes. But look at all the fun you had.  Mind if I try?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You! Don't make me laugh.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're such a smart aleck! Nobody can do anything but you. I'll show you how to stop a carand I won't use my thumb.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What're you going to do?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Mind your own business.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You might give me a little credit.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I proved once and for all that the limb is mightier than the thumb.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why didn't you take all your clothes off? You could have stopped forty cars.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: We don't need forty cars.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What were you going to do? Gold dig him for a meal?[13]

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why not? I'm hungry.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Eat a carrot.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Never!  I'm going in and ask him

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If you do, I'll break your neck.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, Peter! What happened? Are you all right?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Come onget in.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, you've been hurt! There's a cut on

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Come on! come on!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Just a road thief. Picks people up and runs off with their stuff. What a racket!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What'd you give him for the car?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: A black eye.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You don't have to eat the carrots.  Just passed a pond with some ducks in it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Darling!
